title: Discovery – Prepositions with the Ablative (Rest & Relationship)
goals: Recognize prepositions that take the Ablative (in, sub, cum, ē/ex, dē)
Understand rest and relationship rather than motion
Connect peace in grammar to peace in life – Pax

steps.speak: Salve! Welcome to Week 15 Day 1. Last week we learned how to move — today we learn how to rest.
Some prepositions show rest or relationship. They use a special form called the Ablative Case.
Listen and repeat: in hortō – in the garden, sub arbore – under the tree, cum amīcō – with a friend.
Notice the endings –ā and –ō. That’s the Ablative Case! It means 'with' or 'in' something, not motion toward.
Say these slowly: ē templō – out of the temple, dē monte – down from the mountain.
Good! These show origin — where something comes from or rests under.
Now compare: in agrum (into the field – motion) vs. in agrō (in the field – rest).
Faith phrase: Cum Deō ambulāmus – We walk with God. We move, but always in His peace.
Virtue reflection: Peace isn’t stopping — it’s being rightly placed, just as each word belongs in its place.
Quick chant: in + ablative = rest, cum + ablative = with, ē/ex + ablative = from.
Optime! Tomorrow we’ll practice speaking and drawing peaceful Latin scenes.
